title: A Sensory Data Set on Wines of The World
text: Descriptors: origin, color varietal; Suplementary variables: Price; Chemical data: Acidity, Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin; Sensory data: fruity, floral, vegetal, spicy, woody, sweet, astringent, hedonic.

title: PCA on Beers
text: following code loads libraries needed analysis:
code: library(dplyr) library(ExPosition) library(knitr) library(kableExtra) library(ggplot2) library(InPosition) set.seed(564)

title: PCA on Beers
text: data example come package data4PCCAR (loaded present package). following commands get data: data comprise three items * beers: ratings (data frame intensity ratings); * beerColors: vector names colors beers; * descColors: vector names colors descriptors. information dataset available corresponding vignette: vignette("A1_DataBeers").
code: library(R4SPISE2022) data("sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges", package = "data4PCCAR") beers <- sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges$ratingsIntensity beerColors <- sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges$color4Products descColors <- sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges$color4Descriptors

title: PCA on Beers
text: default, function preprocess variables darta set (.e., columns data table) 1) centering (option center = TRUE pre-processing variables mean equals 0) 2) scaling (option scale = TRUE pre-processing variables sum squares equals , number rows).
code: res.pca <- epPCA(beers,                   center = TRUE, # Center the data                  scale = FALSE, # **Do not** scale the variables                  graphs = FALSE)

title: PCA on Beers
text: results.stats: useful statistics performing PCA, among one can find factor scores, loadings, eigenvalues, contributions; results.graphs: PCA graphs (heatmaps, screeplot, factor map, correlation circles, loading maps etc.) description.graphs: titles graphs, used titles PPTX file.
code: res.plot.pca <- OTAplot(     resPCA = res.pca,     data = beers     )

title: PCA on Beers
text: can check data plotting correlation matrix variables. correlation matrix components extracted.

title: PCA on Beers
text: scree plot shows eigenvalues component. eigenvalues give variance component (called dimension figure). words, singular values, square root eigenvalues, give standard deviations components. sum eigenvalues equal total inertia data.  According elbow test, four dimensions keep data.

title: PCA on Beers
text: , observation map shows observations (.e., rows) represented component space. center = TRUE running PCA epPCA, origin center (.e., average / barycenter) observations. (’s , something’s wrong)  result plot showed first dimension separates BlueMoon Hofbrau, second dimension separates BlueMoon Hofbrau FranzDunkel FranzNatur.

title: PCA on Beers
text: circle correlations illustrate variables correlated dimensions. figure, length arrow indicates much variable explained two given dimensions. cosine two arrows gives correlation. cosine variable axis gives correlation variable corresponding dimension. figure, angle closer 0° indicates correlation close 1; angle closer 180° indicates correlation close -1; 90° angle indicates 0 correlation. However, ’s worth noted implication correlation might true within given dimensions. variable far away circle, fully explained dimensions, dimensions might characterized pattern relationship variables.  circle correlation plot illustrates Dimension 1 Sweet Alcoholic versus Yeast, Hay, Bitter, Cereal, Toasted; Dimension 2 Acid Fermented versus Cereal Toasted. Interestingly, Acid Fermented orthogonal Sweet Hay (anti-correlated ) first two dimension. two dimensions, Cereal Toasted negatively correlated Malt Hop.

title: PCA on Beers
text: inference analysis PCA (performed OTAplotInference) includes bootstrap test proportion variance explained, permutation tests eigenvalues, bootstrap tests column factor scores \(\mathbf{G}\) (.e., right singular vectors scaled variance dimension equals corresponding singular value; \(\mathbf{G} = \mathbf{Q}\boldsymbol{\Delta}\) \(\mathbf{X = P}\boldsymbol{\Delta}\mathbf{Q}^\top\)). column factor scores stored fj output epPCA.
code: res.plot.pca.inference <- OTAplotInference(     resPCA = res.pca,     data = beers     ) %>% suppressMessages()

what: Bootstrap and permutation tests on the eigenvalues
title: PCA on Beers
text: inference scree plot illustrates 95% bootstrap confidence intervals percentage variance explained eigenvalue. interval includes 0, component explains reliably larger 0% variance.  bootstrap test identifies one significant dimension explains variance reliably larger 0%. permutation test identifies one significant dimension eigenvalue significantly larger 0.

what: Bootstrap test on the column factor scores
title: PCA on Beers
text: bar plot illustrates bootstrap ratios equals \[\frac{M_{g_{j}boot}}{SD_{g_{j}boot}},\] \(M_{g_{j}boot}\) mean bootstrapped sample jth column factor score \(SD_{g_{j}boot}\) bootstrapped standard deviation factor score. bootstrap ratio equivalent t-statistics column factor score \(\mathrm{H}_0: g_j = 0\). threshold set 2 approximate critical t-value 1.96 \(\alpha\) = .05.   results show significant factor scores dimensions reliably different 0.

what: Load the data and the packages
title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: following command chgu: intensities; chguColors: colors chewing-gums; descColors: colors descriptors.
code: library(R4SPISE2022) data("sixteenGums4Descriptors", package = "data4PCCAR") chgu <- sixteenGums4Descriptors$ratingsIntensity chguColors <- sixteenGums4Descriptors$color4Products descColors <- sixteenGums4Descriptors$color4Descriptors

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: default function center (means equal 0) scale (standard deviations equal 1) variables.
code: res.pca <- epPCA(chgu,                   center = TRUE, # Center the data                  scale = "ss1", # Scale the variables                  graphs = FALSE)

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: results.stats: useful statistics performing PCA, among one can find factor scores, loadings, eigenvalues, contributions; results.graphs: PCA graphs (heatmaps, screeplot, factor map, correlation circles, loading maps etc.) description.graphs: titles graphs, used titles PPTX file.
code: res.plot.pca <- OTAplot(     resPCA = res.pca,     data = chgu     ) %>% suppressMessages()

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: can check data plotting correlation matrix variables. correlation matrix components extracted.

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: scree plot shows eigenvalues component. eigenvalues give variance component (called dimension figure). words, singular values, square root eigenvalues, give standard deviations components. sum eigenvalues equal total inertia data.  According elbow test, 4 dimensions data; , according Kaiser test (eigenvalue > 1), 1 dimension.

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: , observation map shows observations (.e., rows) represented component space. center = TRUE running PCA, origin center observations. (’s , something .)

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: circle correlations illustrate variables correlated dimensions. figure, length arrow indicates much variable explained two given dimensions. cosine two arrows gives correlation. cosine variable axis gives correlation variable corresponding dimension. figure, angle closer 0° indicates correlation close 1; angle closer 180° indicates correlation close -1; 90° angle indicates 0 correlation. However, ’s worth noted implication correlation might true within given dimensions. variable far away circle, fully explained dimensions, dimensions might characterized pattern relationship variables.

title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: inference analysis PCA (performed OTAplotInference) includes bootstrap permutation tests eigenvalues bootstrap tests column factor scores (.e., right singular vectors scaled variance dimension equals corresponding singular value; \(\mathbf{Q}\boldsymbol{\Delta}\) \(\mathbf{X = P}\boldsymbol{\Delta}\mathbf{Q}^\top\)).
code: res.plot.pca.inference <- OTAplotInference(     resPCA = res.pca,     data = chgu     )

what: Bootstrap and permutation tests on the eigenvalues
title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: inference scree plot illustrates 95% bootstrap confidence intervals eigenvalue. interval includes 0, eigenvalue reliably different larger 0.  bootstrap test identifies three significant dimensions eigenvalues reliably different 0. permutation test identifies one significant dimension eigenvalue significantly larger 0.

what: Bootstrap test on the column factor scores
title: PCA on the Chewing-gum Data
text: bar plot illustrates bootstrap ratios equals \[\frac{f_j}{\sqrt{SD_{f_{j}boot}}},\] \(f_j\) column factor scores jth variable \(SD_{boot}\) bootstrapped standard deviation factor score. bootstrap ratio approximates t-statistics column factor score \(\mathrm{H}_0: f_j = 0\). threshold set 2 approximate t-value 1.96 \(\alpha\) = 0.05 (1.96).   results show significant factor scores dimensions reliably different 0.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: following command information dataset available corresponding vignette: vignette("A3_DataWines").
code: data("winesOf3Colors", package = "data4PCCAR") wineColors <- list() wineColors$oc <- as.matrix(as.character(recode(winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors$color, red = 'indianred4',                  white = 'gold', rose = 'lightpink2'))) wineColors$gc <- as.matrix(c(red = 'indianred4',                  white = 'gold', rose = 'lightpink2'))  varColors <- list() varColors$oc[[1]] <- as.matrix(rep("darkorange1", 4)) varColors$oc[[2]] <- as.matrix(rep("olivedrab3", 8))

what: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: PLSC on Wines
code: descr <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(origin, color, varietal) suppl <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(Price) chemi <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(Acidity, Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin) senso <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(fruity, floral, vegetal,             spicy, woody, sweet, astringent,             hedonic)

previous_headings: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: PLSC on Wines
text: First table: chemical data (chemi) includes acidity, alcohol, sugar, tannin. Second table: sensory data (senso) includes fruity, floral, vegetal, spicy, woody, sweet, astringent, hedonic.

previous_headings: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: PLSC on Wines
text: Descriptors: origin, color varietal. Supplementary variables: Price.

what: Run Partial Least Square Correlation (PLS-C) on the two tables
title: PLSC on Wines
text: default function center (means equal 0) scale (sums squares equal 1) variables data tables. argument DESIGN indicates groups observations change observations colored figures (graphs = TRUE), change results PLS-C.
code: res.pls <- tepPLS(chemi, senso, DESIGN = descr$color, graphs = FALSE)

title: PLSC on Wines
text: TTAplot function, DESIGN specified. latent variables colored according groups observations group means 95% bootstrap confidence intervals.
code: ## You might need to load these packages if the error is saying that it couldn't find some functions  res.pls.plot <- TTAplot(     res = res.pls, # Output of tepPLS     color.obs = wineColors, # <optional> colors of wines     color.tab = varColors, # <optional> colors of the two tables     tab1.name = "Chemical data", # <optional> Name of Table 1 (for printing)     tab2.name = "Sensory data", # <optional> Name of Table 2 (for printing)     DESIGN = descr$color, # design for the wines     tab1 = chemi,  # First data table     tab2 = senso)  # Second data table

title: PLSC on Wines
text: can check data plotting first correlation matrix two data sets. correlation matrix dimensions extracted.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: scree plot shows eigenvalues dimension. eigenvalues give squared covariance pair latent variables. words, singular values, square root eigenvalues, give covariance pairs latent variables. sum eigenvalues equal sum squared covariance variables tables.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: , plot first latent variable tables observations colored according groups. plot shows observations distributed dimension chosen pair latent variables related . plotting first pair latent variables, expect observations distribute along bottom-left--top-right diagonal line (illustrates perfect association), PLS-C maximizes covariance latent variables. examine stability groups, plot group means 95% bootstrap confidence intervals (ellipsoids). ellipses overlap, groups reliably different . However, ’s worth noted distribution observations imply groups (represented group means) distributed whether groups reliably different . Note: grouping information independent PLS-C use help provide summary description observations.  results Dimension 1 show association chemical sensory data reliably separates red wines rose white wines.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: bar plots illustrate signed contribution variables two data tables. figures, use direction magnitude signed contributions interpret dimension. direction signed contribution direction loadings, shows variables contribute dimension. variables contribute similar way sign, contribute opposite way different signs. magnitude contributions computed squared loadings, quantify amount variance contributed variable. Therefore, contribution similar idea effect size. identify important variables, find variables contribute average (.e., big enough effect size). variables centered scaled sums squares equals 1, variable contributes one unit variance; therefore, average contribution 1/(# variables table).   two bar plots, first dimension characterized (1) positive association Alcohol Tannin Chemical data Woody Astringent Sensory data, (2) negative association variables Hedonic Sensory data. Together latent variable plot, found , compared rose white wines sample, red wines less Hedonic stronger Alcohol, Tannin, Woody, Astringent.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: circle correlations illustrate variables correlated dimensions. figure, length arrow indicates much variable explained two given dimensions. cosine two arrows gives correlation. cosine variable axis gives correlation variable corresponding dimension. figure, angle closer 0° indicates correlation close 1; angle closer 180° indicates correlation close -1; 90° angle indicates 0 correlation. However, ’s worth noted implication correlation might true within given dimensions. variable far away circle, fully explained dimensions, dimensions might characterized pattern relationship variables.   circles correlations show Alcohol, Tannin, Woody, Astringent, Hedonic strongly correlated Dimension 1 Henodic inversely correlated variables. variables mostly explained first dimension close--zero correlation second dimension (included discussed previous sections).

title: PLSC on Wines
text: inference analysis PCA (performed OTAplotInference) includes bootstrap test proportion variance explained, permutation tests eigenvalues, bootstrap tests loadings (.e., left right singular vectors).
code: res.plot.plsc.inference <- TTAplotInference(     res = res.pls,     tab1 = chemi,      tab2 = senso,      DESIGN = descr$color,     tab1.name = "Chemical data", # <optional> Name of Table 1 (for printing)     tab2.name = "Sensory data" # <optional> Name of Table 2 (for printing)         )

what: Bootstrap and permutation tests on the eigenvalues
title: PLSC on Wines
text: inference scree plot illustrates 95% bootstrap confidence intervals eigenvalues. interval includes 0, eigenvalue reliably larger 0.  bootstrap test identifies two significant dimensions eigenvalues reliably larger 0. permutation test identifies two significant dimensions eigenvalues significantly larger 0.

title: PLSC on Wines
text: bar plot illustrates bootstrap ratios equals \[\frac{M_{p_{j}boot}}{SD_{p_{j}boot}},\] \(M_{p_{j}boot}\) mean bootstrapped sample jth loading \(SD_{p_{j}boot}\) bootstrapped standard deviation factor score. bootstrap ratio equivalent t-statistics column factor score \(\mathrm{H}_0: g_j = 0\). threshold set 2 approximate critical t-value 1.96 \(\alpha\) = .05.  bootstrap test identifies Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin chemical variables loadings significantly different 0.  bootstrap test identifies Floral, Spicy, Woody, Sweet, Astringent Hedonic significant sensory variables loadings different 0. ’s worth noted bootstrap ratio gives different information contributions. Contributions describe size effect, bootstrap ratios describe reliability loadings. Therefore, interpret results, combine draw conclusion.

previous_headings: Inference plots and results > Bootstrap test on the loadings
what: Interpreting loadings with contributions and bootstrap ratios
title: PLSC on Wines
text: results Chemical data show Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin loadings stably (significantly) different 0. , Alcohol Tannin contribute significant amount variance dimension. Although loading Sugar stable significant different 0, effect size small; words, ’s considered important.  Similarly, Sensory data, results show Floral, Spicy, Woody, Sweet, Astringent Hedonic loadings stably (significantly) different 0. , Woody, Astringent, Hedoniccontribute significant amount variance dimension. words, loadings Floral, Spicy, Woody, Sweet, Astringent Hedonic stable reliably different 0, important variables define dimension Woody, Astringent, Hedonic.

previous_headings: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: Descriptors: origin, color varietal. Supplementary variables: Price.

what: Run Redundancy Analysis (RA) on the two tables
title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: tepRA function takes two entries data tables. first entry predictor table (X) second entry predicted table (Y) regression equation: \(\mathbf{Y = \beta X + E}\). RA, dimensions maximize \(\beta\) pair latent variables. default function center (means equal 0) scale (sums squares equal 1) variables data tables. argument DESIGN indicates groups observations change observations colored figures (graphs = TRUE), change results RA.
code: res.ra <- tepRA(chemi, senso, DESIGN = descr$color, graphs = FALSE)

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: TTAplot function, DESIGN specified. latent variables colored according groups observations group means 95% bootstrap confidence intervals.
code: ## You might need to load these packages if the error is saying that it couldn't find some functions # library(PTCA4CATA)  # library(data4PCCAR) res.ra.plot <- TTAplot(     res = res.ra, # Output of tepPLS     color.obs = wineColors, # <optional> colors of wines     color.tab = varColors, # <optional> colors of the two tables     tab1.name = "Chemical data", # <optional> Name of Table 1 (for printing)     tab2.name = "Sensory data", # <optional> Name of Table 2 (for printing)     DESIGN = descr$color, # design for the wines     tab1 = chemi,  # First data table     tab2 = senso)  # Second data table

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: can check data plotting first correlation matrix two data sets. correlation matrix dimensions extracted.

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: scree plot shows eigenvalues dimension. eigenvalues give squared coefficient regression (\(\beta^2\) = 3.14247) pair latent variables. words, singular values, square root eigenvalues, give coefficient regression (\(\beta\) = 1.7727013) pairs latent variables. sum eigenvalues equal sum squared correlation variables tables.

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: , plot first latent variable tables observations colored according groups. plot shows observations distributed dimension chosen pair latent variables related . plotting first pair latent variables, expect observations distribute along bottom-left--top-right diagonal line (illustrates perfect association), RA maximizes coefficient regression latent variables. examine stability groups, plot group means 95% bootstrap confidence intervals (ellipsoids). ellipses overlap, groups reliably different . However, ’s worth noted distribution observations imply groups (represented group means) distributed whether groups reliably different . Note: grouping information independent RA use help provide summary description observations.  results Dimension 1 show chemical data can predict performance sensory data, prediction separates red wines rosé white wines, rosé white.

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: bar plots illustrate signed contribution variables two data tables. figures, use direction magnitude signed contributions interpret dimension. direction signed contribution direction loadings, shows variables contribute dimension. variables contribute similar way sign, contribute opposite way different signs. magnitude contributions computed squared loadings, quantify amount variance contributed variable. Therefore, contribution similar idea effect size. identify important variables, find variables contribute average (.e., big enough effect size). variables centered scaled sums squares equals 1, variable contributes one unit variance; therefore, average contribution 1/(# variables table).   two bar plots, first dimension characterized (1) positive association Alcohol Tannin Chemical data Woody Astringent Sensory data, (2) negative association variables Hedonic Sensory data. Together latent variable plot, found , compared rosé white wines sample, red wines less Hedonic stronger Alcohol, Tannin, Woody, Astringent.

title: Redundancy Analysis on Wines
text: circle correlations illustrate variables correlated dimensions. figure, length arrow indicates much variable explained two given dimensions. cosine two arrows gives correlation. cosine variable axis gives correlation variable corresponding dimension. figure, angle closer 0° indicates correlation close 1; angle closer 180° indicates correlation close -1; 90° angle indicates 0 correlation. However, ’s worth noted implication correlation might true within given dimensions. variable far away circle, fully explained dimensions, dimensions might characterized pattern relationship variables.   circles correlations show Alcohol, Tannin, Woody, Astringent, Hedonic strongly correlated Dimension 1 Henodic inversely correlated variables. variables mostly explained first dimension close--zero correlation second dimension (included discussed previous sections).

what: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: PLSR on Wines (Part 1)
code: descr <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(origin, color, varietal) suppl <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(Price) chemi <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(Acidity, Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin) senso <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(fruity, floral, vegetal,             spicy, woody, sweet, astringent) chemisenso <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(Acidity, Alcohol, Sugar, Tannin, fruity, floral, vegetal,            spicy, woody, sweet, astringent) hedo <- winesOf3Colors$winesDescriptors %>%      select(hedonic)

previous_headings: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
what: PLS-R Part 1: Predicting one variable with a data table
title: PLSR on Wines (Part 1)
text: predictors (X): chemical data (chemi) includes acidity, alcohol, sugar, tannin. predicted (Y): hedonic (hedo).

previous_headings: Two tables with descriptors and other supplementary information
title: PLSR on Wines (Part 1)
text: Descriptors: origin, color varietal. Supplementary variables: Price.

what: Run Partial Least Square Regression (PLS-R) on the two tables
title: PLSR on Wines (Part 1)
text: data4PCCAR::PLSR_SVD function takes two entries data tables. first entry predictor table (X) second entry predicted table (Y) regression equation: \(\mathbf{Y = \beta X + E}\). RA, dimensions maximize \(\beta\) pair latent variables. function center (means equal 0) scale (standard deviation equal 1) variables data tables.
code: res.plsr <- data4PCCAR::PLSR_SVD(chemi, hedo, 3, inference = TRUE, displayJack = TRUE)

title: PLSR on Wines (Part 1)
text: PLSRplot function, DESIGN specified. latent variables colored according groups observations group means 95% bootstrap confidence intervals.
code: ## You might need to load these packages if the error is saying that it couldn't find some functions # library(PTCA4CATA)  # library(data4PCCAR) res.plsr.plot <- PLSRplot(     res = res.plsr, # Output of tepPLS     displayJack = TRUE,     color.obs = wineColors, # <optional> colors of wines     color.tab = varColors, # <optional> colors of the two tables     tab1.name = "Chemical data", # <optional> Name of Table 1 (for printing)     tab2.name = "Hedonic", # <optional> Name of Table 2 (for printing)     DESIGN = descr$color, # design for the wines     tab1 = chemi,  # First data table     tab2 = hedo)  # Second data table

title: Authors and Citation
text: Abdi H (2022). R4SPISE2022: Provides Set Programs, Vignettes, Data SPISE2022 Workshop. http://github.com/HerveAbdi/R4SPISE2022, https://herveabdi.github.io/R4SPISE2022/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {R4SPISE2022: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop},   author = {Hervé Abdi},   year = {2022},   note = {http://github.com/HerveAbdi/R4SPISE2022, https://herveabdi.github.io/R4SPISE2022/}, }

what: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: R4SPISE2022 provide data, programs, documentation SPISE-2022 Advanced Workshop Sensory Evaluation (July 27, 2022 July 28, 2022; take place Hanoi Vietnam).

title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: can install development version R4SPISE2022 following lines code: install vignettes installing package, run following commands:
code: # if remotes is not installed, decomment the following line # install.packages('remotes') remotes::install_github('HerveAbdi/R4SPISE2022') remotes::install_github('HerveAbdi/R4SPISE2022',    build_vignettes = TRUE,   force = TRUE)

title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(R4SPISE2022)  ## load data  data("sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges", package = "data4PCCAR") beers <- sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges$ratingsIntensity  ## run PCA res.pca <- epPCA(beers,                   center = TRUE, # Center the data                  scale = FALSE, # **Do not** scale the variables                  graphs = FALSE)   ## generate plots for descriptive results        res.plot.pca <- OTAplot(resPCA = res.pca,                         data = beers)  ## generate plots for inference results res.plot.pca.inference <- OTAplotInference(resPCA = res.pca,                                            data = beers)

title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: OTAplot(): Core function generate figures descriptive results one table analysis (.e., principal component analysis; PCA) OTAplotInference(): Core function generate figures inference results one table analysis (.e., PCA) TTAplot(): Core function generate figures descriptive results two table analyses (.e., PLSC, CCA, RA) TTAplotInferenct(): Core function generate figures inference results two table analyses (PLSC now) PLSRplot(): Core function generate figures descriptive inference results partial least square regression (PLSR)

title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: sixBeers12Descriptors10Judges sixteenGums4Descriptors winesOf3Colors

title: Provides a Set of Programs, Vignettes, and Data for the SPISE2022 Workshop
text: Principal Component Analysis paper. Partial Least Square Methods: review paper. Canonical Correlation Analysis paper

title: Boostrap for eigenvalues. — Boot4Eigs
text: Boostrap eigenvalues.

title: Boostrap for eigenvalues. — Boot4Eigs
code: Boot4Eigs(   data,   center = FALSE,   scale = FALSE,   design = NULL,   niter = 100,   CI.perc = c(0.025, 0.975),   suppressProgressBar = TRUE )

title: Boostrap for eigenvalues. — Boot4Eigs
text: data data-set; center whether center data (default FALSE), see expo.scale; scale whether scale data ( default FALSE), see expo.scale; design whether design; niter number bootstrap iterations; CI.perc vector two levels confidence left right limits bootstrap confidence interval (default c(0.025, 0.0975)); suppressProgressBar whether show progress bar (default TRUE).

title: Boostrap for eigenvalues. — Boot4Eigs
text: list containing four objects

what: Core function to generate PLSR plots. — PLSRplot
title: Core function to generate PLSR plots. — PLSRplot
text: Core function generate PLSR plots.

title: Core function to generate PLSR plots. — PLSRplot
code: PLSRplot(   res,   displayJack = TRUE,   tab1,   tab2,   leDim = c(1, 2),   color.obs = NULL,   color.tab = NULL,   title.plot = "Results",   alpha.points = 0.25,   DESIGN = NULL,   sigbar.p = FALSE,   sigbar.q = FALSE,   tab1.name = "J-set",   tab2.name = "K-set",   TI = FALSE,   mean.cex = 3,   mean.textcex = 3,   only.mean = FALSE,   only.ind = FALSE,   score.constraints = NULL,   mean.constraints = NULL,   scale.mean.constraints = 3,   save2pptx = FALSE,   title4pptx = "PLSR Results" )

title: Core function to generate PLSR plots. — PLSRplot
text: res result two-table analysis; displayJack whether plot jackknife results; tab1 result two-table analysis; tab2 result two-table analysis; leDim vector containing dimensions plotted; color.obs list containing colors observations; color.tab list containing colors two-tables; title.plot plot title; alpha.points opacity points; DESIGN design observations; sigbar.p whether plot significant bars contribution plot first block (default FALSE); sigbar.q whether plot significant bars contribution plot second block (default FALSE); tab1.name name first table (default "1"); tab2.name name second table (default "2"); TI whether plot tolerance intervals (default FALSE); mean.cex size expansion mean symbols; mean.textcex size expansion mean symbols; .mean whether plot means; .ind whether plot observations latent variable plot (default FALSE); score.constraints constraints plot (use care); mean.constraints constraints plot (use care); scale.mean.constraints constraints plot (use care). save2pptx Default: FALSE title4pptx Title PPTX, Default: 'TTA Results'.

title: Core function to generate PLSR plots. — PLSRplot

what:
PlotScreeWithCI ----
plot the scree for the eigenvalues
of an SVD based multivariate analysis,
and add bootstrap confidence intervals. — PlotScreeWithCI
title:
PlotScreeWithCI ----
plot the scree for the eigenvalues
of an SVD based multivariate analysis,
and add bootstrap confidence intervals. — PlotScreeWithCI
text: PlotScreeWithCI: Plot scree eigenvalues SVD-based multivariate analysis. Note function can recompute eigen-values percentage given. example  ExPosition return ev requested one. return percentage max.ev specified, used recompute eigenvalues. default PlotScree plot line corresponding average inertia (.e., Kaiser criterion). provided probabilities, PlotScree color differently "significant" eigenvalues.

title:
PlotScreeWithCI ----
plot the scree for the eigenvalues
of an SVD based multivariate analysis,
and add bootstrap confidence intervals. — PlotScreeWithCI
code: PlotScreeWithCI(   ev,   p.ev = NULL,   max.ev = NULL,   ci.ev = NULL,   ci.tau = NULL,   polygon.ci = "tau",   alpha = 0.05,   col.ns = "#006D2C",   col.sig = "#54278F",   title = "Explained Variance per Dimension",   xlab = "Dimensions",   plotKaiser = FALSE,   color4Kaiser = "darkorchid4",   lwd4Kaiser = 2.5 )

title:
PlotScreeWithCI ----
plot the scree for the eigenvalues
of an SVD based multivariate analysis,
and add bootstrap confidence intervals. — PlotScreeWithCI
text: ev eigenvalues plot. default. p.ev probabilities associated eigen-values, (default = NULL). max.ev max eigenvalue needed ExPosition always return eigenvalues sometimes requested ones; however ExPosition always returns percentages .e., tau), max.ev specified, used recompute eigenvalues. ci.ev, confidence intervals eigenvalues, computed Boot4Eigs. Default NULL. ci.tau, confidence intervals taus, computed Boot4Eigs. Default NULL. polygon.ci, confidence intervals plot. 'tau' plot bootstrap confidence intervals taus; 'ev' plot bootstrap confidence intervals eigenvalues; NULL plot polygon. Default 'tau'. alpha threshold significance Default = .05). col.ns color non significant eigenvalues. Default 'Green'. col.sig color significant eigen-values. Default 'Violet'. title title graph default "Explained Variance per Dimension". xlab names dimensions (default 'Dimensions'). plotKaiser TRUE plot line corresponding average inertia (Kaiser criterion); plot FALSE (default). color4Kaiser color Kaiser's line (default 'darkorchid4') lwd4Kaiser lwd value (.e., width) Kaiser's criterion line. (default '2.5')

title:
PlotScreeWithCI ----
plot the scree for the eigenvalues
of an SVD based multivariate analysis,
and add bootstrap confidence intervals. — PlotScreeWithCI

code: TTAplot(   res,   tab1,   tab2,   leDim = c(1, 1),   leDim4CirCor = c(1, 2),   color.obs = NULL,   color.tab = NULL,   title.plot = "Results",   alpha.points = 0.25,   DESIGN = NULL,   sigbar.p = FALSE,   sigbar.q = FALSE,   tab1.name = "J-set",   tab2.name = "K-set",   TI = FALSE,   mean.cex = 3,   mean.textcex = 3,   only.mean = FALSE,   only.ind = FALSE,   score.constraints = NULL,   mean.constraints = NULL,   scale.mean.constraints = 3,   save2pptx = FALSE,   title4pptx = "TTA Results" )

title: Core function to generate two-table analysis plots. — TTAplot
text: res result two-table analysis; tab1 result two-table analysis; tab2 result two-table analysis; leDim vector containing dimensions plotted; leDim4CirCor vector containing dimensions correlated latent variables circle correlation plot; color.obs list containing colors observations; color.tab list containing colors two-tables; title.plot plot title; alpha.points opacity points; DESIGN design observations; sigbar.p whether plot significant bars contribution plot first block (default FALSE); sigbar.q whether plot significant bars contribution plot second block (default FALSE); tab1.name name first table (default "1"); tab2.name name second table (default "2"); TI whether plot tolerance intervals (default FALSE); mean.cex size expansion mean symbols; mean.textcex size expansion mean symbols; .mean whether plot means; .ind whether plot observations latent variable plot (default FALSE); score.constraints (default NULL) constraints plot (use care); mean.constraints (default NULL). constraints plot (use care); scale.mean.constraints constraints plot (use care). save2pptx Default: FALSE, TRUE save graphs PowerPoint file. title4pptx Title PPTX, Default: "TTA Results".

title: Core function to generate two-table analysis plots. — TTAplotInference
text: res result two-table analysis; method method used; 'PLSC' 'CCA' (default 'PLSC'); tab1 first data table; tab2 second data table; center1 variables tab1 centered (default TRUE); scale1 variables tab1 centered (default "ss1"); center2 variables tab1 centered (default TRUE); scale2 variables tab1 centered (default "ss1"); leDim vector containning dimensions plotted; leDim4CirCor vector containning dimensions correlated latent variables circle correlation plot; color.obs list containing colors observations; color.tab list containing colors two-tables; title.plot plot title; alpha.points opacity points; DESIGN design observations; sigbar.p whether plot significant bars contribution plot first block (default FALSE); sigbar.q whether plot significant bars contribution plot second block (default FALSE); tab1.name name first table (default "1"); tab2.name name second table (default "2"); TI whether plot toerance intervals (default FALSE); mean.cex size expansion mean symbols; mean.textcex size expansion mean symbols; .mean whether plot means; .ind whether plot observations latent variable plot (default FALSE); score.constraints constraints plot (use care); mean.constraints constraints plot (use care); scale.mean.constraints constraints plot (use care). save2pptx Default: FALSE title4pptx Title PPTX, Default: 'TTA Results'.

and generate the standard graphs and tables.

code: OTAplot(   resPCA,   data,   DESIGN = NULL,   make_design_nominal = TRUE,   k = 0,   graphs = 12,   printGraphs = FALSE,   col4I = NULL,   col4J = NULL,   biplot = FALSE,   rotation = FALSE,   nfactor4rotation = "Kaiser",   show.TI = FALSE,   show.CI = TRUE,   mean.cex = 3,   mean.textcex = 3,   display.labels.ind = FALSE,   display.labels.var = TRUE,   display.points.mean = TRUE,   mean.constraints = NULL,   scale.mean.constraints = 1.5,   max.n4bar = 40,   max.n4heat = 50,   title.size.heatmap = 20,   save2pptx = FALSE,   title4pptx = "PCA Results" )  OTAplotInference(   resPCA,   data,   DESIGN = NULL,   make_design_nominal = TRUE,   k = 0,   graphs = 12,   printGraphs = FALSE,   col4I = NULL,   col4J = NULL,   biplot = FALSE,   rotation = FALSE,   nfactor4rotation = "Kaiser",   niter.boot = 100,   niter.perm = 100,   save2pptx = FALSE,   title4pptx = "PCA Inference Results" )  graph4epPCA(   data,   scale = TRUE,   center = TRUE,   DESIGN = NULL,   make_design_nominal = TRUE,   k = 0,   graphs = 12,   printGraphs = FALSE,   col4I = NULL,   col4J = NULL,   biplot = FALSE,   rotation = FALSE,   nfactor4rotation = "Kaiser",   inferences = FALSE,   save2pptx = "",   title4pptx = "PCA Results" )

title:
create the graphs for a PCA analysis
from ExPosition
and generate the standard graphs and tables.
Note: Still Under Development. — OTAplot
text: resPCA Output InPosition::epCA.inference.battery data data frame matrix numerical data suitable PCA. Passed ExPosition::epPCA. DESIGN Default: NULL. design vector (factor character) (Boolean) matrix used assigne oobservations groups. Passed ExPosition::epPCA. make_design_nominal TRUE (Default) transform vector DESIGN Boolean matrix. Passed ExPosition::epPCA. k number factor keep; equql 0  (Default), factors kept. Passed ExPosition::epPCA. graphs want graphs? Current Default 12 indicates graphs generated first 2 components. Note current version creating output first two components, printGraphs (Default: FALSE) want print graphics .png? col4I color vector plotting observations (NULL Default) use colors ExPosition::epPCA. col4J color vector plotting variables (NULL Default) use colors ExPosition::epPCA. biplot De want create biplots (Default: FALSE)? rotation want rotate (varimax) variables (Default: FALSE) nfactor4rotation number factors keep rotation, number (note number big nfactor4rotation default 2), name (currently 'Kaiser' default). 'Kaiser' chosen, keep components eigenvalue larger average (scaled == 'SS1' familiar rule: "keep components eigenvalue larger 1"). show.TI whether plot tolerance intervals . Default: FALSE show.CI whether plot confidence intervals . Default: TRUE mean.cex size dots means. Default: 3 mean.textcex size texts means. Default: 3 display.labels.ind TRUE, labels observations printed. Default: FALSE. display.labels.var TRUE, labels variables printed. Default: TRUE. display.points.mean TRUE, mean factor scores plotted. Default: TRUE. mean.constraints list constraints (include minx, miny, maxx, maxy) constraints figure includes means. constraints used .mean = TRUE. Default: NULL scale.mean.constraints value used scale constraints (multiplication). function used adjust constraints confidence tolerance intervals outside figure. Default: 1.5 max.n4bar number bars exceed value, labels hidden. Default: 40. max.n4heat number row/columns heatmap exceed value, labels hidden. Default: 50. title.size.heatmap size title heatmaps. Default: 20. save2pptx Default: '' yet implemented, title4pptx PARAM_DESCRIPTION, Default: 'PCA Results'. yet implemented,. niter.boot (default = 100) many iteration bootstrap mean DESIGN variable. niter.perm (default = 100) many iteration permutation test eigenvalues. scale scale (.e., normalize) columns data. Default: TRUE. Values TRUE, FALSE, 'Z', 'SS1'. TRUE defaults SS1. Passed ExPosition::epPCA. center Default: TRUE. center columns data Passed ExPosition::epPCA. inferences Run inferences InPosition Remains done, Default FALSE.

title:

into a PowerPoint file. — saveAllGraphsInList2pptx
text: saveAllGraphsInList2pptx: nifty function saves PowerPoint file graphics given list (Possibly titles given additional list). Requires packages rsv officer.

title:
saves all the graphics in a list
into a PowerPoint file. — saveAllGraphsInList2pptx
code: saveAllGraphsInList2pptx(   list2Save,   titles4list2Save = NULL,   file2Save.pptx = "PowerpointFromR",   title = NULL,   addGraphNames = TRUE )

title:
saves all the graphics in a list
into a PowerPoint file. — saveAllGraphsInList2pptx
text: list2Save list graphics (created ggplot2 Recordplot). titles4list2Save list (number items list2Save) serve title graphs. NULL (default) title graph name graph list2Save. file2Save.pptx (default = "PowerpointFromR") name PowerPoint file saving graphs. file already exists, old file renamed warning message printed console. title main title PowerPoint file. default: "Graphics R" + date. addGraphNames TRUE (default) put titles powerpoint slides; titles provided titles4list2Save used, name graphs used title slide.

title:
saves all the graphics in a list
into a PowerPoint file. — saveAllGraphsInList2pptx
text: list (class "save2pptx")  listOfsavedGraphs (list graph objects saved)  nameOfSavingFile4pptx (name file graphics saved). Note: print one graphs nameOfSavingFile4pptx, use print(get()). example, print first graph list saved listOfGraph use print(get(listOfGraph$listOfsavedGraphs[[1]])).
